column1: Aurangabad furnished a genial soil for the spread of Islam
column2: and was the centre of great missionary movements in the 8th century of the Hijri. The district is home to the earliest of Sufi saints of the Deccan. The town of Khuldabad contains the shrines of the most famous saints of the Dakhan. Initially it was known as Rauza meaning "garden of paradise". It is known as the Valley of Saints
column3: or the Abode of Eternity
column4: because in the 14th century
column5: several Sufi saints chose to reside here. The tomb of the Mughal emperor Aurangzeb and his trusted general Qamar-ud-din Khan
column6: Asaf Jah I first Nizam of Kingdom of Hyderabad are located in this town
column7: so is the tomb of Malik Ambar.

column1: There is scarcely a village in the district which is without its tomb to its patron saint
column2: known by the general name of "Aulia". "Saiad" "Wali"
column3: or "Sadat". The "Urs" or the anniversary day of each saint is observed by the Muhammedans and weekly offerings are also made at some of the principal shrines
column4: on every Thursday or Friday. The following is a brief account of the chief Muhammedan saints of the district and the different orders to which they belonged.

column1: Founded by Baha-ud-din whose surname was Nakshbandi
column2: the painter.

column1: Baba Shah Mosafar was one of the most celebrated Nakshbandis of Aurangabad. He was born at Ghajdavan and studied at Bukhara under Baba Palang Posh Nakshbandi. As Hasan Abdal
column2: his spiritual preceptor gave him his final initiation of Baiat and invested him with the cap and mantle. Baba Shah Mosafar travelled over Bengal and Orissa
column3: and arrived at Aurangabad by way of Ginj and Hyderabad. He resided in the tekkieh (convent) of Shah Enalit in Katabpura; but resumed his travels again
column4: and after proceeding as far as Mecca
column5: returned once more to Aurangabad. Shah Mosafar was not welcomed this time by Shah Enait
column6: and moved to the Mahmud darwaza
column7: where Sherin Ali Shah
column8: an Azad or free dervish was living. The Azad was well versed in theological literature
column9: but had a regular tavern for his dwelling place as he belonged to the Be-shara class of fakirs
column10: who are hermits and live without the law. However
column11: he courteously gave up the mosque
column12: and retired to Sultanganj; and Baba Shah Mosafar cleared the place of the bhang drinking vessels. As he belonged to  fakirs who are travellers and pilgrims living within the law. Shah Mosafar settled down to a monastic life
column13: and was visited by various prominent persons
column14: who reconstructed his humble dwelling with more substantial materials
column18: and a system of water-supply with cisterns and fountains. Among those who called on him

column2: Muhammad Tahir of Persia
column3: haji Manzur
column4: a eunuch of the royal harem. Hafiz Abdul Maoni a learned poet of Balkh
column5: and Tahir Beg of Tashkand. Muhammad Kalich Khan gave him the jagir of Kasab-Khera in the Elora pargana
column6: and a mansab of 150 Rs. a month. The emperor Bahadur Shah expressed a wish to call on him
column7: but sent the prime minister instead. And afterwards the emperor's son prince Muiz ud din visited the Baba. Shah Mosafar died in H. 1110
column8: and in H. 1117. Turktaz Khan Bahadur
column9: a noble on the staff of Nizam ul Mulk 'Asaf Jah' erected the present handsome stone tekkieh the mosque
column10: and the Panchaki or water-mill. Twenty years later Jamil Beg Khan added the-ablong reservoir with fountains
column11: in honour of which
column12: the poet Saiad Gholam 'Ali Bilgrami composed a Mesnavi and consecrated it to Imam Husain.

column1: Mir Muhammad of Walkan in Bukhara succeeded Shah Mosafar as Kaliph and went to Karnul with Khaja Koli Khan
column2: a companion to Chin Kalich Khan
column3: where he was killed in a scuffle in H. 1119.

column1: Khaja Yadgar Khan worshipped in the mosque of Jamil Beg Khan
column2: and received an annual allowance from the emperor Aurangzeb.

column1: Saiad Masum lies buried towards Sangvi for whom Aurangzeb built the Shabina masjid.
Rehmat Alla Shah came from Baghdad in the time of Aurangzeb
column2: and stayed in Mosafar Shah's tekkieh for thirty years. He then returned to Aurangapura
column3: where Mir Khalil
column4: the emperor's steward
column5: built him a mosque
column6: etc. Rehmat Alla Shah sent his Kalish Hussain Ali to Jalna.

column1: Suhrawardiyya order sprang from the Nakshbandi order at Baghdad
column2: and was founded by Shahabu-d din in H. 602.

column1: He was the earliest saint of suhrawardiyyah order to visit abdi mandi in daulatabad before 601 Hijri.
Saiad Shah Jalal ud din or Ganj Rawan Ganj Baksh (which means "moving treasure')
column2: was born at Khirkan near Bukhara
column3: and established the earliest Islamic mission in the Dakhan about H. 700
column4: or a little before the invasion of 'Alaud din Khalji. He settled down at Unasnagar
column5: between Daulatabad and Roza. Ganj Rawan's tomb at Roza has two trees growing near it
column6: one of which is reputed to have grown from a staff given him by his preceptor
column7: and the other from a branch of the first. Both are said to possess miraculous properties.

column1: Shahab ud din was an able author
column2: who flourished in the 9th century Hijri
column3: and wrote several works. He spent the greater part of his life at Daulatabad of which he was the "kazi"
column4: and had a dispute with Saiad Ajmal the minister of justice about Saiads and Ulemas. Shahabud din died at Daulatabad about H. 848.

column1: Nizam ud din came into the Dakhan with a number of Mahomedan missionaries in the beginning of the 11th century of the Hijri era
column2: and lived at 'Ambad. He possessed great literary qualifications
column3: and Malik Ambar appointed him "kazi" of 'Ambad. His son Baha ud din suffered martyrdom at Ahmednagar
column4: where his tomb is still venerated. Nizam ud din's daughter was buried with her husband at  "Nag-jhari"
column5: a mile south of 'Ambad. A document dated H. 1113 in the possession of the present descendant
column6: is sealed by Amjad 'Ali Khan Fiawar
column7: an employee of Shah 'Alam Badshah Ghazi.

column1: Shah Latif Tawizi came to Paithan and was invested with spiritual power by Maulana Muizzu-d din. His tomb on the bank of the Godavari
column2: opposite to Maulana Sahib's darga
column3: is without a dome.

column1: Dawal Shah Wali or Abdul Malik Latif is said to have been the groom of 'Ali. After the death of his master
column2: Dawal Shah Wali travelled about; and monuments were erected to his memory in the different places which he visited. In this manner
column3: there are about 360 "chillas" to him in the Dakhan
column4: besides numerous "astanas" containing some of his sacred relics. He suffered martyrdom  at Kattiawad. A "chilla" to Dawal Shah Wali is found within the city walls of Aurangabad to the left of the Mecca gate
column5: and is resorted to every Thursday by Mahomedans and Hindus. The poor people ascribe all manner of sickness to Shah Wali
column6: and make offerings to his tomb. There is another "chilla" to him at Elora
column7: and a shrine to his mother called "Man sahib ki chilla." Babulgaon in the Gangapur taluka
column8: and Pipalwari 6 miles from Paithan
column9: have "astanas" to Shall Wali. Two more "astanas" occur in the Baijapur taluka.

column2: with Saiad 'Abdul Kadar Gilani whose shrine is at Baghdad
column3: and is the chief order of fakirs in the district.

column1: Shah Nasir ud din or Shah Nasir Alla Kadar was instructed by Said ud din of Delhi to accompany Burhan ud din to the Dakhan on a religious mission. The party arrived at Pirbohra
column2: a village 24 miles north of Aurangabad
column3: where the members separated.

column1: Shah Nasir erected the earliest mosque in Jalna on the site "tekri" or mound not far from the   "ashaba"
column2: . Jala Rao
column3: or Mahomed Islam Khan
column4: a freebooter whom Shah Nasir converted
column5: built the "Khas bhag"
column6: and on his death which happened in a religious war
column7: Nasir Alla became possessed of the "shish" or mud fort. Nasir Alla died in the 8th century Hijri
column8: and was buried on the Aurangabad road
column9: not far from the "shish."

column2: one of the seven patron saints of Jalna
column3: was a learned man of Delhi
column4: who accompanied Burhanu-d din to the Dakhan
column5: and separated from him at Pirbohra. He opened two "maktabs" or schools near the Jama Masjid at Jalna
column6: and his tomb lies close by. Students offer sugar on the threshold of the tomb
column7: in the hope of improving their memories.

column2: reservoir
column3: and tomb at Wakla in the Baijapur taluka
column4: to Luta 'Ali Shah of the Kadari order
column5: who arrived in the Dakhan about 400 years ago.

column1: Saiad Rahman or Saiad Rafi came with Aurangzeb
column2: and settled at Jalna. The Malis or gardeners give an annual feast called "kundun" at his tomb in Anandi's garden beyond the 'Ambad darwaza.

column1: Tajud din and Saifud din of Baghdad
column2: the descendants of 'Abdul Kadar Jilani
column3: proceeded to Mecca
column4: and then came to India
column5: where they separated. Tajud din arrived at Aurangabad in H. 1070
column6: and on his way
column7: converted a band of robbers 14 miles north of the city
column8: some of whom settled down on the spot and founded a village called Tajnanur. He subsequently became a recluse
column9: and retired into a cave on Chaman Tekri
column10: to the east of Daulatabad
column11: where he was accidentally discovered by Aurangzeb when out hunting. The saint was taken out in a very emaciated state
column12: and was attended by the emperor's physicians who carried him to the Bharkal gate of Aurangabad. Tajud din improved in health
column13: and his staff which was buried in the ground began to grow after forty days. The emperor ordered a mosque to be erected at Chaman Tekri and called it "Taimur Beg masjid". In the meantime Ruknud din
column15: who had been left behind at Baghdad
column16: as being too young to travel
column17: had heard nothing of Tajud din for twenty years
column18: and traveled by way of Mecca for the Dakhan in search of his father. At last he came to the mosque at Chaman Tekri where he obtained news of Tijud din
column19: and soon afterwards joined the latter at the Bharkal gate in the city. On the ensuing "Urus" of 'Abdul Kadar Jilani
column21: under the title of Mir Mahomed Shaikh Soliman
column22: was appointed successor to his father. Tijud din had an aversion to music and singing
column23: and earned his livelihood by carpet-weaving. He died in H. 1110
column24: and his darga stands near the Bharkal gate of the city.

column1: Syed Qadar Auliya is among the descendants of Huzoor Syed Shaikh Abdul Qadir Jilani baghdadi. His tomb lies near jafar gate area near Sunday market in Aurangabad. He is the 9th descendant of Syed Shaikh abdul Qadir Jilani.
Ruknud din or Shaikh Soliman left two months later for Mecca
column2: and returned to Aurangabad after an absence of nine months. He died in H. 1156
column3: and was buried near his father. Chin Begam
column4: the daughter of 'Asaf Jah
column5: was a staunch disciple of Ruknu-d din's
column6: and was buried near him in H. 1161. An inscription mentions that Saiad Shah Aziz Badshah
column7: the grandson of Ruknud din
column8: erected the present darga in H. 1190. He also composed a small Persian work in H. 1291
column9: called "Nokat-a-Azizi"
column10: and dedicated it to his son Saiad Shah Azim Badshah
column11: tutor to the Nizam.

column1: Syed Shahnoor Mohammed Hamvi Jeelani Qadri (Shahnoor miya)
Shahnoor miya was the 9th grandson of Bade Peer Sarkar. He came from Baghdad and lived for some time at Burhanpur and then at Ahmadnagar. He visited Aurangabad after Aurangzeb's arrival
column2: and initiated nawab Diyanut Khan
column3: the emperor's minister
column4: into the Kadaria order. He died in H. 1104
column5: and was buried outside the Paithan gate of the city of Aurangabad. Shahoor miya's tomb was built by Diyanat Khan Sahab. His age was 350 years. He is left with only one descendant in Barely Syed Shah Ahmedullah Qadri Jeelani. Urs at dargah is celebrated with great devotion and devotees and attends the urs from all the region from Aurangabad
column6: Hyderabad etc. The silsila continued after him was named as Silsila e Nooriyah.

column1: Sayyed Muhammad shah Quadri was 25th grandson of sultan shaikh abi Muhammad Mohiyuddin Abdul Qadir Al-gilani. He came from the chaklamba Shareef (beed). He lived at some time in khadki he visited to paithan after order of his brother Sayyed Amiruddin Quadri(chaklamba Shareef). Today Also his descendants live their life in paithan. His elder son Hazrat Sayyad Kadar Badshah Quadri was also a sufi saint
column2: very well known in ahmednagar city also.He Made his khanqah in paithan
column3: where he used to teach sufism to his mureedin. At present the current Sajjada Nasheen Of khanqah is  Hazrat Sayyad Ashfaq Quadri Al-Jilani Saheb. There is also a great book in this khanqah which was brought by Great-Grandfather Of Sayyad Muhammad Quadri
column4: Whose Name Was Hazrat Sayyad Noor Muhammad Quadri
column5: Al-Jilani. His shrine is situated in a village Umapur
column6: Beed. That book was translated into udru From arabic
column7: by Ulema of badaun under guidance of sayyad kadar badshah quadri. That book is divided in four parts
column8: 2 parts are printed for public and another 2 are remaining. Name of that book is "Saif E Dastageer" It consists Sayings And spiritual Teachings of shaykh abdul kadir jilani

column1: Shah Unas Kadari flourished at Harsul in the time of Aurangzeb. He probably came from Constantinople
column2: and belonged to the Kavas-jilar order of dervishes. Kanduri is a feast held in his honor. The elders of the "Kalbay Kadar ka fakir" come from Bidar to Siwar in the Baijapur taluka. The members of this order are often absorbed in silent meditation
column3: with eyes closed or fixed on the ground.

column1: There is a Kalbay Kadar tekkieh at Badnapur near Jalna
column2: and another close to the Killa Arak in the city of Aurangabad. When the latter was deserted
column3: it was sold to the Shiahs of the city
column4: who converted the place into a burial ground. The wealthier Shiahs only temporarily interred their dead in the cemetery
column5: and afterwards transferred the remains to Kerbela. Shaha Jang
column6: uncle of the late Sir Salar Jang
column7: was buried in this cemetery. An inscription over his tomb gives the date of his death as H. 1210.

column1: Chishti Order contains some of the most famous saints of the Dakhan.
Syed Shah Muntajabuddin Zar Zari Zar Baqsh

column2: surnamed Zar Zari Zar Baksh
column3: meaning "generous"
column4: was one of the earliest of the Chishtias
column5: and was sent to the Dakhan by Nizamuddin Auliya of Delhi
column6: in the beginning of the 8th century Hijri. He was accompanied by 700 disciples
column7: and is said to have converted a Hindu princess near a well at Roza. The place is called "Sohan baoli" or "pleasing well"
column8: and the princess is buried close to the saint.

column1: The tomb of Zar Zari Baksh is between Malik Ambar's tomb and the northern gate of the town. It contains a number of ornaments and relics
column2: the most remarkable of which is a circular looking-glass of steel mounted on a steel pedestal of four feet in height. It is said to have been presented by king Tana Shah.

column1: Shah Burhan ud din studied under Nizamuddin Auliya
column2: the sultan ul mashaikh of Delhi; and Saiad Mahomed of Karmania relates in the "Seyar ul Aulia"
column3: that Burhanud din was invested with the mantle and cap
column4: the symbols of the kaliphat
column5: in succession to the sultan ul mashaikh. Other writers state
column6: that on the death of Shah Muntajab ud din at Daulatabad
column7: his brother Burhan ud din was sent to succeed him
column8: and was accompanied by 1
column9: 400 disciples. It appears more probable however
column10: that Burhan ud din succeeded the sultan ul mashaikh as kaliph
column11: and that he emigrated to the Dakhan when sultan Muhammad bin Tughluq  transferred the capital from Delhi to Daulatabad. Mujud ud din in his "Bakiat-el-Gharib" gives a biography of Burhan ud din; and haji Saiad Baksh and Shams ud din
column12: the nephew of Hasan bin es Sanjari
column13: were the particular friends of the saint. Burhan ud din allowed music and dancing in the religious exercises at his convent. He remained for some time at Daulatabad and then left for Roza
column14: where ho died in approx. H. 741 (1344 AD).

column1: Opposite the building which contains the tombs of Aurangzeb and Zain-ud-din is that of Shah Burhanud din. It has a large quadrangular courtyard having open fronted building on all sides
column2: and a nagarkhana at the east end. The west end of the quadrangle is used as a school and a door here gives access to an inner courtyard containing several graves. Facing the entrance is the tomb of Sayyad Burhan-ud-din. Within the shrine are preserved some hair of Muhammad's beard. The shrine doors are plated with plates of metal wrought into fanciful designs of trees and flowers. There is a mosque in front of the dargah.

column1: Shaikh Zain ud din Daud was born at Shiraz in H. 701 and went to Delhi by way of Mecca. He studied under Maulana Kamal ud din of Samana
column2: and came with him to Daulatabad. The author of the "Mayrat-al Walayeh" mentions that Zain ud din on his arrival at Daulatabad
column3: disapproved of the singing and dancing in the convent of Burhan ud din; but when he visited the "tekkieh"
column4: he was perfectly satisfied
column5: and he and his companions were initiated in the Chishtia order. Shaikh Zain ud din held the office of "kazi" at Daulatabad
column6: and in H. 737 was invested with the mantle of the kaliphat
column7: but did not actually succeed till after Burhan ud din's death in H. 741. Shaikh Husain has recorded all the sayings of Zainu-d din in his "Hidayat ul Kalul"
column8: and mentions that in H. 747
column9: sultan Muhammad bin Tughluq directed him to leave for Delhi with the other inhabitants. After the death of the sultan
column10: his successor Firoz Shah permitted the saint to return to Daulatabad. Zainu-d din was greatly respected by the Bahmani king sultan Mahmud
column11: who was first reproved by the saint for misgovernment. Malik raja the founder of the Faruki dynasty of Kandesh became one of Zainu-d din's disciples
column12: and when the next sovereign Nasir ud din Nasir Khan Faruki captured Asirgarh in A.D. 1399
column13: Zainu-d din went expressly from Daulatabad to Asirgarh
column14: to tender his congratulations. It was to commemorate this visit that the town of Zainabad
column15: on the left bank of the Tapti
column16: was founded after him; and Burhanpur on the opposite bank was founded about the same time in honor of Burhan ud din. Zain ud din died in H. 771
column17: and a handsome mausoleum was erected over his tomb at Roza
column18: which is visited by devout Musalmans of the Dakhan. The relics of the "parahan" (the robe of Muhammad) and "taj" given to Burhanu-d din on succeeding to the kaliphat
column19: are carefully preserved in a wooden box placed in one of the apartments of Zain ud din's darga. Every year on the 12th Rabiu-l Awal
column20: the sacred hair of Muhammad is first shown to visitors
column23:
and a few likenesses of some of the most sacred personages among the Mahomedans are exhibited.
The tombs of Azam Shah, of his Begum, and of a Mahomedan saint, are in a small enclosure to the east of Zainu-d din's mausoleum; while Aurangzeb's tomb lies to the west. Opposite this last is a large quadrangular courtyard, having open-fronted buildings on all sides, and a nakar-khana" or music hall at the east end. The west end is used as a school where the Koran is taught
column24: and gives access to an inner courtyard which contains a number of graves. Facing the entrance is the shrine of Burhan ud din; and a little to the right is the last resting-place of Asaf Jah and of one of his consorts. To the left is the tomb of Nasir Jang
column26: who at one time contemplated rebellion against his father
column27: but overcome by contrition for his conduct
column28: performed penance at the tomb of saint Zain ud din.

column1: Saiad Yousaf or Shah Raju Qatal was instructed by Charagh Dehlwi to proceed to the Dakhan
column2: and arrived there in H. 726. He was accompanied by his sons Saiad Chanda and Saiad Mahomed Banda Nawaz surnamed "Gaysu Daraz" or "the long-ringletted." The latter is the patron saint of Gulbarga. Saiad Yousaf was a Sufi "mashaikh"
column3: and wrote a religious
column4: poem called "Tuhfet-en-nasayeh." He died in H. 726 and was buried at Roza.

column1: Amir Hasan bin es Sanjari came from Seistan also known as Amir Hasan Dihlawi Sijzi and was a disciple of Nizamuddin Auliya. He was called the "Sadi of Hindostan"
column2: and recorded all his preceptor's sayings in the "Fawaid-ul Fawad." His "Lataif-al-Ashrafi" is full of jokes; and his writings were eulogized by Jami the Persian poet
column3: by Shaikh Faizi
column4: and by others. He left for Daulatabad on the transfer of the capital from Delhi
column5: and died in H. 737. His tomb is outside of Roza
column6: and is surrounded by a wall
column7: but has no dome over it. Students offer sugar on the threshold of the tomb on Thursdays
column8: to improve their memories. A mosque and "tekkieh are attached to the tomb; and close by is the grave of the poet Mir Gholam Ali Azad Bilgrami of the 12th century Hijri."

column1: Maulana Farid ud din the Adib was one of the leading disciples of Burhdn ud din and died 17 days before his preceptor. His tomb lies to the west of that of Muntajab ud din.
Haji Husain was born at Shiraz
column2: and was a merchant. His son Zain ud din started for Mecca en route to India; and haji and his brother came to Delhi in search of Zain ud din. They then left for Daulatabad where they settled down and died
column3: and were buried to the north-east of Roza. In former days
column4: religious Mahomedans spent 40 days in this dome
column5: in prayer and fasting.

column1: Nizam ud din came in the 8th century Hijri
column2: and Burhan ud din gave him a "turra" or crest for his turban
column3: and the title of "Saidus Sadat" or "chief of chiefs." He left Daulatabad for Paithan
column4: and on his way
column5: he erected a mosque and dome. Saiad Sadat performed a "chilla" or fast for 40 days within the dome
column6: and after his death a cenotaph was raised to his memory. The patelship of the village of Bhirkan which he populated
column7: was for a long time in the hands of Saiads
column8: whose tombs are scattered over the kasba and pet
column9: and are objects of veneration to the inhabitants. He peopled the eastern portion of the town and died in H. 792. On the Urus day
column10: the spire of the dome over his tomb is adorned by the Mainars or builders of Paithan with a "turra" or tuft
column11: at the ceremony called "turra churhana"
column12: to commemorate the crested turban which Saiad Sadat wore. The Mainars
column14: and the descendants of the Moghals and Persians who settled about Paithan in the time of Aurangzeb
column15: are among the "khadims" of Saiad Sahib. A date stick
column16: and a "kutchkoal" or beggar's bowl which belonged to the saint
column17: are carefully preserved in the darga. Newly married persons perambulate the tomb three times
column18: and place offerings of food in the beggar's bowl. Bawa Ramzan or Kanoba was a Hindu sorcerer who was converted by Saiad Sadat. He was called Bawa Ramzan
column19: from having been converted in the month of Ramzan; and died at Tisgaon Marri near Ahmednagar. He was held in great reverence; and a pitcher with which he drew water for 12 years and filled a large jar for Saiad Sadat to wash in
column20: is preserved in the darga.Jalaluddin Pir Manik Bhandari

column1: He is also amongst the earliest disciples Khalifa of Nizamuddin Auliya Mehbub e Ilahi Delhi. He ran the Langar khana of Nizamuddin Auliya. He went to the Deccan with Burhanuddin Gharib with 1400 palki
column2: and became famous by the name of Bhandari. His shrine is in Fatehabad Taluka Gangapur District Aurangabad of Maharashtra.His Grand family is living in Aurangabad Maharashtra. And they are conducting Urs shareef every year continuously. His current Sajjada Nashin is Sufi Shaikh Tajuddin Chisty Bhandari & Nayab Sajjada Nashin is Sufi Shaikh Fayazuddin Chisty Bhandari.
a rich dervish
column3: accompanied Aurangzeb in his early expeditions into the Dakhan
column4: and retired to Gangapur where he died. His darga is in the "barra tekkieh" close to the "shahi bagh" or royal garden. A cenotaph and lamp-pillar to Zinda Shah Madar were also erected in the "barra tekkieh" by Azmat ul la
column5: a son of Soliman Shah who joined the Khadman sect of the Madaria order.

column1: Habib ul la or Hakkani Haknuma flourished at Ranjani in the Jalna taluk; and respect is paid to his memory by the Hindus and Mahomedans
column2: especially by the females. Jana Shah Mian came in the time of the first Nizam
column3: and settled at Seona
column4: where he practised fixed meditation. A hill six miles from Kanhar
column5: near Nandarbari
column6: is called "Kalandar-ki-pahar"
column7: possibly after one of the Kalandri order
column8: which is a branch of the Chishtia. Shah Bu Ali Kalandar came with Burhan ud din
column9: and is said to have had his seat on a huge boulder
column10: close to one of the Kanhar hills. Great reverence is paid to this boulder by the Hindus and Mahomedans of the surrounding country. Shah Bu Ali afterwards went to the Punjab and died there. The Mewatis of Kunjkhaira in the Kanhar taluk
column11: belong either to the Chishtia or some other branch of the Kadaria order. A little to the east of Kunjkhaira is a darga to Jangli Shah Mian
column12: and another to Chumman Shah Dulah.

column1: Shattari - A branch of the Kadaria
column2: in which the members repeat their devotions with great rapidity. Arif Alla Shah was about the earliest arrival in the Dakhan
column3: who belonged to this sect. He was buried in his "tekkieh" outside the western gate of 'Ambad
column4: near a mosque about 400 years old
column5: called "Bin khami masjid." Saiad Ahmad of Gujarat spread the Shattaria sect in Aurangabad Maharashtra
column6: probably in the time of Aurangzeb. He was a follower of Burhan ud din
column7: and his shrine is outside the Jafar gate.

column1: Razzaq Shahi is a branch of the Kadaria
column2: founded by Abdul Razak of Baghdad. Arif Shah Sain of this sect came to 'Ambad
column3: where he erected a mosque. His "tekkieh" and tomb are to the north of 'Ambad; and the graves of his six successors are close by. Sher 'Ali Shah Sain arrived from the Panjab
column4: and his "tekkieh" and tomb are near the Shahgarh darwaza of'Ambad. The remains of a furnace are close by
column5: where he made amber beads which he distributed to fakirs
column6: etc. Shah Khaksar came from Bijapur to Roza in the time of Akbar
column7: and his "tekkieh" and tomb are at Sulibhajan.

column1: Shah Khaksar came from Bijapur to Roza in the time of Akbar
column2: and his "tekkieh" and tomb are at Sulibhajan. He established the Khaksari sect at Daulatabad; and the graves of several of his followers are near his tomb.

column1: Mohkam Shahi is another branch of the Kadaria to which Data Wali of 'Ambad belonged. Data Wali never left his "tekkieh" which is outside the Jalna darwaza
column2: and when he died
column3: was buried in the convent.

column1: Jan Alla Shahi is a sect founded at Jalna by Jan Mohammed
column2: who was born at Sinnur near Delhi in H. 1030. He was early left an orphan
column3: and started with his brother for Baghdad; and on completing his studies
column4: was instructed at the tomb of 'Abdul Kadar Jilani to proceed to the great spiritualist
column5: Miranji of Burhanpur. After studying with Miranji for five years
column6: Jan Mahomed's name was changed in open congregation to Jan Alla (Life of God)
column7: and that of his brother to Bab Alla (Door of God). In H. 1046 he started for Mecca accompanied by the ancestors of the present "khadims;" and on his journey
column8: was assisted by the "Jins."

column1: After an absence of twelve years Jan Alla was instructed to proceed to Jalna
column2: which he did by way of Baghdad. On arriving at Aurangabad
column3: he occupied a chamber on the left of the Jumma masjid of Malik Ambar
column4: and was quite a recluse
column5: performing the "Sunnat" prayers in his own room
column6: and only the "Fars" prayers in the mosque. His sanctity was noised about
column7: and he was invited to Jalna by haji Bur Khurdar the faujdar. Aurangzeb also wished to see him and went for the purpose to the Jumma masjid
column8: and even to the "Hujra" or chamber
column9: but did not succeed in his object. A copy of a letter is still shown
column10: which is said to have been written to Jan Alla by order of Aurangzeb. The emperor next sent his vizier
column11: but before the latter could come
column12: Jan Alla and his brother had quietly gone away to Mungi Paitan
column13: and from thence proceeded with Abdur Rahman
column15: to Jalna. Aurangzeb then sent prince Muazzam to Jalna
column16: and the saint received the prince kindly in a small dwelling in a mango grove where Jan Alla's tomb has since been erected. It was on this occasion that Jan Alla received a sanad for five hundred bighas of land near Jalnapur
column17: where Kadrabad and the cantonment now stand.

column2: or Janaza Rawan
column3: a "khadim" of Jan Alla
column4: conducted the funeral services for the colony of Kadrabad. He compelled the "Jins" to carry him on his cot to Bijapur
column5: to meet Shah Azimu-d din or "Tazim Turk" who mistook him for Jan Alla. Of the other "khadims"
column6: Hidayat Alla in H. 1070 copied Imam Gazib's work in the Kufio character. In H. 1085 Ali Bin Mohammed wrote the Monovarul Kalub
column7: a work on spiritualism. Haji Shah Ismail was buried at Bajipura in Aurangabad ; and his grandson Amam Alla's tomb is near Jan Alla's in Jalna. Amam Alla wrote a Persian work in H. 1169. Saiad 'Abdulla was a "mohudis" versed in tradition; and Mian Haji Mohammed Kasim was tutor to Bahadur Shah I. Miral Hasan was a studious khadim who died at Haidarabad
column8: and his remains were transferred to Kadrabad. He was a prominent subject of Nasir-ud-Daula
column9: and was contemporary with Maulvi Shaja ud din of Haidarabad
column10: and Alla Wali Sahib of Burhanpur
column11: two of the most learned men of the time. Nur-al Hasan or Gholami Sahib collected a number of books
column12: and had the honor of bringing from Mecca
column14: and a sacred book called Dalail-us Sharif
column15: which he kept in Jalna. The clan of Ghori Pathans found about Jalna belong to the "khadims" of Jan Alla. They fought under Ranmust Khan against raja Sambha of Sattara; and Nahir Khan
column17: held Jalna in jaghir. According to an inscription
column18: Nahir Khan built the 'Ambad darwaza with a bastion on each side
column19: and a well and masjid for his spiritual director Shah Miran. There is another mosque close by
column20: which was built by Sultan Mohammed

column1: Nirgun Shah Wali came from Bengal
column2: and lived as a recluse at Nidhara
column3: two miles north of Jalna. His principle was
column4: "retirement from the eyes of the world
column5: and cessation from seeking the honor and respect of any one." When Aurangzeb was at Jalna
column6: he is said to have visited Nirgun Shah Wali. Many others called to see him
column7: including Jan Alla
column8: Bab Alla
column9: Raja Bagh Sawar
column10: and Nirgun received them
column11: seated on a stone which is still pointed out. He also paid return visits
column12: and took with him a starling (maina)
column13: which was always his companion and was able to talk. There is a story current
column14: that Nirgun was murdered by the patels of Nidhara and Tandulwara
column15: for the sake of this maina
column16: which Jan Alla coveted It is said that three days after Nirgun's death
column17: Jan Alla gave a great feast to all the dervishes
column20: maina pointed out the corpse of Nirgun
column21: and denouncing Jan Alla as his murderer
column22: fell down dead upon its master. From that day
column23: Jan Alla was stigmatised as "Jan Alla maina mar"
column24: and the fakirs of the Nakshbandi
column30: and the numerous sects to which these gave rise
column31: consider the khadims of Kadrabad out of caste and will not eat with them. The khadims on the other hand deny the accusation
column32: and assert that there was no talking bird
column33: but that the maina refers to a woman named mana. They further state that the woman was instructed to say that she had been cruelly wronged
column34: because the other dervishes were envious of the 500 bigahs of land which the khadims possessed. Regarding Nirgun the khadims and the patels of Nidhara and Tandulwara affirm
column37: in one of his acts of worship called "Tahajud"
column38: the intensity of his devotion was so great
column39: that his head and limbs fell asunder. (The word "Nirgun" suggests a connection with "Nirvana"
column40: and the story of this saint has an under-current of Buddhism. The Buddhists sympathised with Mahornedanism
column41: and Nirgun's maina is probably the Daitya mana who is said to have been killed by Khandoba. The reverence paid to sacred boulders is derived from the aborigines; and raja Bagh Sawar
column42: and even Jan Alla and Bab Alla are believed to have been converted Hindus.)

column1: Rafai - Founded in Syria in the 6th century Hijri by Saiad Ahmad Rafai
column2: nephew to Abdul Kadar Jilani. The Rafais are celebrated for their penances with red-hot irons
column3: and are also called howling dervishes. The order was introduced into Aurangabad by Rahmat Alla Shah Rafai in the time of Aurangzeb; and the members became very numerous in the days of Nizam 'Ali Khan
column4: when there were 360 houses belonging to them in Aurangabad. During the subahship of Shabar Yar Jang
column5: the Rafais cut themselves with lances whenever alms were refused them.

column2: etc.

and lived for thirty years in Mosafar Shah's "tekkieh" at Panchakki. He then moved into a house in Aurangpura which Aurangzeb's steward built for him. His tomb is beyond the western gate of Aurangabad. Medina Sahib came from Medina
column3: and his frenzy as a Rafai is still spoken of by dervishes. He was buried inside the Jafar darwaza. Masum Shah was a famed Rafai of Tisgaon Mori
column4: ten kos from Paitan towards Ahmadnagar. He often visited Kadrabad and built a "tekkieh" near the "Ranger khirki." He was buried in front of the "darga" of Nur Shah Wali. Chand Bi founded Chandaigaon in the Baijapur taluk
column5: and held it in fief under Malik Ambar. It is said that the earth from the grave of Chand Bi has a salutary effect on those bitten by snakes
column6: so that she probably belonged to the Saadi order
column7: the fakirs of which go about with snakes. The ordinary snake jugglers of the district are called "Miran-Summa-ka-garuri"
column8: and are followers of Miran Sum-ma
column9: whose shrine is at Mirj Tajgaon near Kolhapur.

column1: Biabani order originated with a disciple of Nizamuddin Aulia(Delhi)
column2: called 'Abdullah'
column3: who interceded with the emperor Babar on behalf of certain Saiada
column4: but without success. He then retired to Mandur and requested the governor to be allowed to dwell unmolested in the "Biabani" or desert
column5: from which the order took its name.

column1: The Biabanis of 'Ambad are descended from 'Abdul Karim the son of 'Abdulla. According to some writers
column2: 'Abdul Karim and four of his relatives went to "Ambica" or 'Ambad near Jalna in Maharashtra
column3: and hence they were called "Biabani" or children of the desert. They settled down near a Hemad Panti well called "Mahadari baoli" in proximity to the "Shamsher masjid"
column4: and were known as the "Panj Pir Biabani" or the five Biaban elders. 'Abdul Karim belonged to the Rafai order
column5: and Ziauddin married the daughter of Sankaray Sultan Mushkil 'Asan
column6: whose shrine is at Kandahar near Nanded. The tombs of the five Biabanis are within the walls of the 'Ambad fort
column7: and are situated to the north.

column2: the son of Abdul Karim
column3: who was born in H. 811 at 'Ambad
column4: became the Rafai kaliph in H. 811
column5: and died in H. 909. His fakirs inhabited the village of Fukrabad
column6: a mile from 'Ambad; and a hill close by
column7: on which he was fond of spending his time in meditation and prayer is called "Fukrabad-ka-pahar." The tombs of his mother and wife are also at Fukrabad
column8: and are called respectively "Pirani Man" and "Bua Man." Offerings of sugar-candy and dates are made to the former. The Biabanis have a tradition that Ziauddin was on one occasion seen by a woman in a convulsive state of religious ecstasy. The woman swooned away
column9: but recovered after an hour
column10: and observed something moving under a scarlet cloth (sakilat). In her fright
column11: she called out "Sakilati Sahib" several times
column12: which attracted the attention of passers by
column13: but on examination the movement ceased
column14: and only a "sakilat" or scarlet cloth was found. To commemorate this event
column16: which for eight months in the year is much frequented by the surrounding population and by the women in particular; but it is not visited during the rains. (This would seem to correspond with the Buddhist "Wassu" or period of sacred rest which was observed during the four months of the rainy season.) The tomb is called "Baghwan" and "Sakilati Sahib" or "Sakalati Bawa"
column17: and sacrifices and offerings are made to it on Thursdays and Fridays. It is thus a source of revenue
column18: and was a subject of dispute between two rival parties. A commission was appointed in H. 1284
column19: which settled the matter in favor of the "khadims" of Ravna and Parora. These assert that 'Alau-d din was buried beneath the tomb in the nalla
column20: and that they are the descendants of his "khadims."

column1: Syed Alauddin(Daulatabad) was the son of Ziauddin
column2: a native of Gujarat
column3: who married a daughter of Burhan ud din and died at Roza. He visited the tombs of the saints of Gulbarga and Bidar
column4: and was returning to Roza by way of 'Ambad
column5: when he is said to have encountered a troublesome band of demons
column6: and in fighting with them
column7: 'Alau-d din suffered martyrdom. The "sakilat" or scarlet cloth which he wore served as a shroud for his remains
column8: and hence he is called "Sakilati Sahib."

column1: Shah Ashraf the son of Ziaud din assisted the army of a governor of Daulatabad
column2: who changed the name of 'Ambika to Ambad
column3: and endowed the "tekkieh" at Fukrabad with lands and cash. There is a local saying that "Ashraf the Biabani supplies bread to the hungry and water to the thirsty."

column1: Sangreay Sultan is reckoned among the great saints of the Dakhan. His tomb is at Kandahar in the Nanded district
column2: and there is a "chilla" to him on the platform above the subterranean passage in the Daulatabad fort. Some Hindus think that the "chilla" contained an image of Ganpati
column3: and say that it was removed to Kaigaon Toka in H. 1207. The place is held in more or less reverence by both Mahomedans and Hindus
column4: and especially by the females. According to a "khadim" at Roza
column5: who is the guardian of this "chilla"
column6: Sangreay Sultan came with the missionaries who accompanied Burhan ud din
column7: and his proper name was Ain ud din. The missionaries separated at Roza
column8: and Ain ud din proceeded to Kandahar
column9: but before leaving for that place
column10: he performed a "chilla" or fast at Daulatabad.

column1: He is well known by his title "Bane Miya".
His tomb is in Aurangabad. Muhammad Azam Shah Biabani is a disciple of Shah Afzal biabani of kazipet.
Muhammad Abdul Hamid Miya Sahab Biabani Qadri
A disciple of Bane Miya of Aurangabad. His tomb is near Jama Masjid Aurangabad.
Madaria - One of the four Tafuria sects founded in Asia Minor by Badi ud din Rustami surnamed Zinda Shah Madar. The Madaria is in four subdivisions: Diwangan
column2: Talban
column3: Ashkan
column4: and Khadman. Some of the fakirs are jugglers
column5: or talk about bears
column6: monkeys
column7: etc. from place to place; while others go about playing on a fiddle and singing in praise of Shah Madar. The Madaria do not shave their beard and moustaches on being initiated; and when any person has gained the object of his desires
column8: he invites the fakirs of this order to perform a ceremony called dhammal. Those who allow their hair to grow are called malang
column9: and adopt celibacy like their preceptor.

column2: also called Shah Nur Ganj Lashkar
column3: and Shah Daud Ganj Lashkar Maghrobi
column4: two Madaria fakirs
column5: came to Roza and Aurangabad respectively
column6: to propagate the tenets of their order. Shah Nur Ganj's tomb is near the "Nakhar Khana" gate of Roza; and Sultan Saiad Shah Nur
column7: one of his kaliphs
column8: was buried near the Pangri gate. Zabarak Ali Shah
column9: another kaliph
column10: was taken by Nizam 'Ali Khan to Hyderabad
column11: but he subsequently returned to Roza where he died
column12: and was buried near the Chauk. Shah Daud Ganj Lashkar Maghrobi introduced the suborder Diwangdn into Aurangabad. His tomb stands near the "tekkieh" called "Til-ki-Mundi."

column2: Salaikaon
column3: Dhamori
column4: Borgaon
column5: and Lasur in the Gangapur taluk; at Kandalla in the Baijapur taluk; and at Roza
column6: inhabited by one or more fakirs of the Khadman subdivision; while Salal Ghogargaon and other villages contain "tekkiehs" of the Diwangdn subdivision. The Talban sect is not represented.

column1: Chingi Shah came about a hundred years ago to 'Ambad
column2: and introduced the Ashkan subdivision. Joat 'Ali the Sain
column3: also of this subdivision
column4: came from northern India and died at Debgaon Murmi in the Gandapur taluk in H. 1275. He was accompanied by a Hindu ascetic
column5: who retired to Kaigaon Toka; and was himself a Kanoja Brahman
column6: but was subsequently converted. Joat 'Ali was also called "Malang Shall Maharaja"
column7: and was in great repute among Hindus and Mahomedans.

column1: Tabkati - The fakirs of this order beg from door to door and many of them are athletes. The athletic arts and the "talims" of Aurangabad owe their origin to Pir Murshad Chatan Shah who came from Upper India in the 17th century of the Christian era. Fata Shah was an athlete of Aurangzeb's time
column2: and won a wrestling match at Mujunburj
column3: one of the bastions near the Delhi gate
column4: against "Makhna pahalwan"
column5: an Ahir athlete. He was buried in the "Fata Shah-ki-talim" to the left of the road loading into the Paitan gate. At the foot of the grave is the tomb of his friend Mausaras
column6: a Hindu convert; and close by are the tombs of Pir Murshad Chatan Shah and of two others.

column1: Dewana nawab or the mad nawab was an athlete who had charge of the great doors of the Delhi darwaza. His tomb is near the Aiwaz-Khan-ki-baradari. Aplatun Khan came with Aurangzeb. He broke the tusk of a wild elephant that was set on him
column2: and dashed it against the "Hathi darwaza". Shah Kuds Shah was a very strong man of Jalna
column3: and a large boulder which he lifted is shown within the Nagar darwaza. This stone is chunamed every year
column4: and is held in great reverence. A smaller boulder which stands near is said to cure persons suffering from lumbago. The Hindus ascribe the healing properties to a certain "taili" or oilman; and offer "gur" and "chana" to the stone. Shah Kuds Shah was buried near his "talim" outside the Nagar darwaza; and mothers bring their children when they begin to walk
column5: and present offerings to the tomb.

column1: Sada Sohag owes its origin to Musa Sohag of Ahmedabad. The members dress in women's attire
column2: and wear a "dupata" of deep red colour. About 50 years ago
column3: Bahar' Ali Shah of Tonk sent two Sada Sohag fakirs
column4: Golah Shah and Chamali Shah
column5: to Aurangabad. They lived in Nawabpura
column6: and erected a "tekkieh" to the right of the Jafar darwaza. Chamili Shah went to Haidarabad
column7: and Golah Shah subsequently joined him
column8: but died soon after his arrival and was buried at Gadjigora. Shah Bungri Lahil of this order was buried in front of the "Rakash-ki-masjid" at Jalna. Young Muslim women visit the tomb to consult their prospects of marriage
column9: and tie a piece of cloth on the "turbet" in evidence of their "nazars" or vows. After marriage
column10: they offer prayers at the tomb
column11: and present one of their marriage bangles.

column2: and probably belonged to the "Ehl-ul-Huk" or People of Truth. His tomb is at Goraigaon in the Baijapur taluk.
an ancient village in the Baijapur taluk
column3: has a tomb to Said Sahib under a "bar" tree (ficus indica). Bhikan Shah Wali accompanied Burhan ud din
column4: and his tomb is under an old tree at Loni Khurd on the Nandgaon road. He came with his mother and his horse; and the latter is buried close to his master. The tomb is called "Ghora-Pir-ki-kabar"
column5: and the Kunbis make offerings to it when their cattle fall sick. A large and elegant mausoleum was erected about 400 years ago at Wakla
column6: by a Hindu convert
column7: Bibi Bohra Khatum. It has seven tombs inside
column8: with two smaller ones in two of the inner corners
column9: and eighteen other tombs in the verandah. There is a story current that a certain person Achal Rao had two sons
column10: Amai Rao and Yeswant Rao. Amai Rao became a Mahomedan
column11: and he and his family are buried in this mausoleum.

column1: Mir Mahomed Shah of Badakshan was made killadar of Peotala fort by Aurangzeb. He belonged to the Vaisi sect
column2: and was buried at Harsul. Mir Fukru-d din Aurangabadi Tirmusi was a Sufi doctor who composed several Persian verses. Shah 'Ali Sahib Barri was a recluse who lived in the hill to the north-west of Aurangabad. Shah Ali Sahib Shairi lived within the city; and so did Shah Ali Sahib Nabari
column3: who constructed canals. Saiadi Sahib
column4: a religious Abyssinian
column5: lived in the shop of a poor dyer in the "chauk "of Aurangabad. Offerings of flowers
column6: etc.
column7: are placed on his tomb. A ruined mosque inside one of the gateways of the Daulatabad fort was erected by a Mohammadan of great sanctity; and to the right of the last entrance is Pir Kudus Sahib's darga. Elora has a shrine to a Mahomedan saint which is visited by large numbers of Hindus and Mahomedans.

column2: etc.

column1: Tuttu Sodagar was a wealthy merchant of Surat and a Bohra by caste
column2: who built the "Tuttu" darwaza of Jalna in H. 1126. He died near the 'Ambad gate
column3: on his way back from Rakisbon
column4: and was buried near the mosque which he built. There were six other rich Musalmans
column5: and in former days Jalna was noted for its wealth. According to an old Urdu proverb
column6: "the children in Jalna were lulled to sleep in cradles of gold"
column7: and a kasar or dealer in bangles named Gangaji
column8: is said to have had such a cradle. Malis and poor people offer fruit to Pir Ghaib Sahib's tomb in front of the "Tuttu" darwaza. Similar presents are made to the darga of Dervash Shah Awaz on the Aurangabad road
column9: especially by the dhobis
column10: in order to preserve the clothes in the "bhattis" from getting burnt The inhabitants of Jalna pray for worldly success at Shah Shumli's tomb; and mothers offer supplications at Pir Darbari's tomb
column11: so that their children may attend "darbars"
column12: or become courtiers. Shah Mauik's tomb is in the "churi mohulla "of Jalna
column13: where glass bangles are manufactured and sold. Shah Shubli had his residence in the "manik chauk"
column14: and was a follower of 'Abu Bekr Shubli
column15: a renowned mystic Shaikh of Baghdad. Musi Makai possessed a valuable library
column16: and was buried in the Ashaba to the north of Jalna.

column2: etc.
inside the Mecca gate
column3: together with the "hammam" or bath
column4: and the "sarai." He also constructed the large tank at Jalna
column5: and laid down pipes and reservoirs for the water supply of the city. Jamshad Khan flourished in the 10th century of the Hijri
column6: and was buried in his garden to the north of Jalna. The cultivators sacrifice to his tomb
column7: so that their erops may not suffer. A masjid at Georahi
column8: not far from Jalna
column9: is resorted to by Hindus and Mahomedans
column10: as it is believed to possess powers of divination. A saint Rafi ud din is said to have possessed similar powers
column11: and his masjid has a "woqf" or pious legacy of 200-bigahs of land
column12: granted by Aurangzeb.

column1: Bahar Khan was a religious man who came from Bidar to Ranjani in the 8th century Hijri. A mosque beyond Ranjani was built by his wife Ayisha Bi
column2: and near it is the darga of Latif Shah Aulia. Gudar Shah Wali arrived in Aurangzeb's time
column3: he erected a mosque. A mound called "Islam tekri" at 'Ambad contains an old Mahomedan building known as "Fatehay Islam" or the "conquest of Islam". A piece of land at the foot of the tekri is appropriated as a "waqf" in support of the mosque. Nur Shah Wili's tomb is outside the Shahgarh darwaza. He made lanterns
column4: which the inhabitants purchased as votive offerings; and at his death he left his money to a Hindu devotee. The "chilla" of Maul 'Ali is on one of the tekris of 'Ambad. The Jumma masjid is ascribed to Malik Ambar. The Mecca masjid is attributed to a devout Musalman who constructed it about 200 years ago; while others affirm that it was raised by the Kharar Khani Pathans who served in Holkar's army. A colony of these Pathans settled at 'Ambad
column5: and built a mosque to the west of the town. 'Ambad further contains a "Kadami Resul" or footprint of Muhammad
column6: which is placed on a brick platform covered over with a small dome
column7: within the Auranga'bad gate There is a tradition that seven Saiads of Arabia were commissioned to deliver Paitan from four goddesses
column8: Hatai Devi
column9: Durga Devi
column10: Revona Devi
column11: and Agna Devi; and that on their arrival
column12: they were arrested and imprisoned in a cave.

column2: popularly called Maulana Moaz
column3: or Maulana Sahib
column4: a native of Shiraz
column5: proceeded to Mecca at an early age
column6: and was directed to liberate the seven Saiads. He left for Paitan
column7: which was then presided over by Revona Devi; and in a battle fought outside its walls
column8: lost many faithful attendants and disciples. The Maulana triumphed in the end
column9: and the seven Saiads were released; but they died soon afterwards
column10: and their tombs are pointed out in a mosque called "Sat-Saiadon-ki-masjid." The saint's darga
column11: which stands in front of this mosque
column12: has a little room attached to it for holy meditation; and his disciples resort to this room in times of difficulty. Each Momin or Mahomedan weaver of Paitan subscribes 8 annas per cent from his income for the maintenance of the darga. According to some people
column13: the Maulana obtained his surname of "Moaz"
column15: from having saved a ship that was foundering; and according to others
column16: he received the name from having miraculously brought up waves of water to quench the fires of the goddess Agni. Dancing is allowed at his darga
column17: and the Urus is observed by Hindus as well as Mahomedans.

column2: etc.
and had a contest with a demon called Goglia
column3: who presided over a village of that name in British territory 1Â½ miles from Paitan. Both 'Abdulla and Goglia perished
column4: and the former was buried beyond the mud walls of the village. Sona Mian
column5: called also Eusaini Saiad and Siddiki Shaikl was another companion of the Maulana's
column6: and suffered martyrdom at Seogaon
column7: 14 miles from Paitan. His head was buried at Khontaphul
column8: 2 miles nearer Paitan
column9: and the body at Seogaon. Shah Mian Duryai
column10: a general merchant of Arabia
column11: possessed many ships
column12: and it was one of these that Maulana Moaz is said to have saved in a storm. He gave up his wealth and joined Maulana's band
column13: and his tomb is inside the gateway of the saint's darga. Shah Mian erected a mosque
column16: within the precincts of the darga.

column1: Moizu-d din the Bhandari came with the band of missionaries that accompanied Mantajabu-d din; and his duty was to take charge of the stores and distribute cooked provisions to the different members. He was also surnamed "Nanpash"
column2: or the bread-giver. After the party arrived at Roza
column3: Moizu-d din and five others left for Gangapurbarri
column4: the present Gangapur. A gosain was practising austerities in a "mat"
column5: from which he retired before the newcomers; and the Nanpash and his party dismantled the building and erected a mosque on the site. Gangapurbarri was then infested with freebooting Mangs
column6: the Mangs offered human sacrifices. The saint tried to convert these outlaws
column7: when a religious war ensued; and in H. 748
column8: the Nanpash
column9: Saiad Kharay Pir Pakhar Sahib
column10: and many others suffered martyrdom. The survivors however
column11: succeeded and a mausoleum to the Nanpash was built. Newly married couples kiss the threshold of the tomb; and presents of food
column12: etc. are offered in times of sickness. The nakarkhana attached to the darga was built by a Kharar Khani Pathan in fulfilment of a vow. The tomb of Saiad Kharay Pir Pakhar Sahib is to the east of Gangapur
column13: and is frequented by the poorer people on Thursdays.

column1: The Mangs continued their depredations till the advent of the seven Saiads
column2: who surprised the freebooters
column3: and numbers of the latter settled down to a peaceful life; but the wilder spirits still kept at large
column4: and in a subsequent raid
column5: succeeding in killing the seven Saiads. After this
column6: the depredations gradually ceased
column7: as the Saiads destroyed the jungle of brush wood that was used as an ambush. The descendants of the Saiads were also made patels of Gangapurbarri
column8: an office which is still partly in their hands. A legend about Gangapurbarri relates that a Mahomedan saint miraculously supplied a large quantity of "ganda" or sugar-cane juice
column9: to some ruler who was passing by and was famishing with thirst. When the prince heard the name of the place
column10: he requested that it should be called "Naishakarpur
column11: '" in reference to the sugar-cane juice; and this was changed to a similar word in Hindostani
column12: Gandapur. The "Shahi Bagh"
column15: but it exists in name only
column16: and is covered with cultivation. When the"janazah" or bier of the emperor Aurangzeb was being carried from Ahmadnagar to Kuldabad
column17: it was kept for the night in the "Shahi Bagb." A "chilla" or cenotaph was erected on the spot
column18: but it has since fallen down. A similar "chilla" was built at Botaibargaon

column1: Saiad Sadat of Waluj came with the Mahomedan missionaries of the 8th century Hijri
column2: and lost his head in fighting at Balore in Berar; but the body is reputed to have continued fighting till it reached Waluj
column3: where it fell down and was buried. The darga was erected in H. 1100 by a Beldar
column4: in fulfilment of a vow
column5: and is frequently visited by the villagers. Behind the darga is the tomb of Saiad Sadat's brother
column6: Saiad Summon
column7: who came with him from Balore. A niee tree close by is said to possess some remarkable qualities.

column1: Kanhar has a darga to Saiad Sahib
column2: another to Sidi Sahib
column3: and a third to Imam Sahib. A mosque near the kacheri was built by Momin Khan
column4: one of the Khatkar Pathans who were stationed at Kanhar to protect the country from the ravages of the Bhils. There is a darga at Pisora to Muskin Shah Mian; and another called "Chihal-tan-ki-darga" contains a brick that was brought from Medina. Sillode possesses a masjid erected by Haji Kabir of Northern India. He was made Kazi
column5: as well as Khatib
column6: of the Seona pargana
column7: by Aurangzeb. Arif ud din surnamed Mogar Shah Wali
column8: is the patron saint of Ajanta
column9: which was formerly called Ranjani or Anjani. He died in H. 1101
column10: and was buried beneath a neem tree. His tomb is propitiated in times of sickness
column11: and the "Dub ghat
column12: or Chusmah Mogar Shah"
column13: where he occasionally performed a "chilla" or fast
column14: is also visited. Bokardan has a darga to Bahir Shah Walli.
